Sep 6 2008 	Another great stay!	I go to NYC often, and stay at the Marriott Marquis usually once a year, most recently for 3 nights in August. This was my 5th stay at the hotel and it was another pleasant one. I arrived around 10:00-10:30 AM, and as I expected, my room wasn't ready. I had requested a king bed room. The front desk clerk was very friendly, as were the bellmen and all staff I encountered. He gave me a card telling me when to come back, and also took my cell phone # in case they were able to call to tell me when the room was ready. I actually was able to get in a little bit earlier than they had said, which was good. My room was # 4154, and it was fine. The view wasn't of Times Square, but I wasn't expecting that, as it costs extra. It was a bigger than average NYC hotel room with a comfortable king size bed, very nice flat screen HDTV, with DirectTV that offered many channels (but went out briefly during a storm, which is somewhat expected at times with a satellite). The flat screen TV's must have just been added in the last year, as my stay last year around the same time didn't have one. There was also a comfortable chair with a footstool, coffee table, and sofa, which I think could be pulled out into a bed. There was also the desk with the $16.95 wired internet (billed noon to noon), which worked fine. I've never had problems at this hotel with the internet service. There was also a coffee pot and alarm clock with Ipod docking station. A couple years ago I stayed here, and there was bottled water for free in the bathroom. Last year is when I started noticing they upgraded it to Fiji water and started charging you. In my room it was sort of hid behind the TV, with a note on it that said you'll be charged in full if water is removed for 30 seconds, so be aware of that! I don't even know how much it cost, but I'm guessing it wasn't too cheap for water! I had used the online "virtual concierge" before I arrived, which is a Marriott standard where they offer little extras (for a fee of course) that are in your room shortly after you arrive. I chose this time mixed nuts and root beer, and when I got into my room, it was already there on a wooden tray on the coffee table, a nice big bowl of mixed nuts and 3 nice, refreshing bottles of root beer on ice and two glasses! The hotel's location is ideal. It's right directly in the middle of Times Square, so your right in the middle of all the hustle bustle! The subway is across the street, so you can get on that to go anywhere quickly, and other attractions are within walking distance, like all the Broadway theatres (there's also a theatre right at the hotel), Rockefeller Center (Top Of The Rock is a can't miss!), 5th Avenue etc... The hop on hop off bus is right outside the hotel, and there's always taxis available within minutes right outside the front door. The TXTS half price ticket booth is right across the street also. The hotel is very busy, it's very popular for conferences as well as tourists, so be prepared for that, it's a huge hotel. I didn't eat at the hotel, so I can't comment on that, but I know the restaurants aren't cheap. There is The View on the top floor, which is the revolving restaurant. I don't think I've ever ate at any restaurants at the hotel during any of my stays there. The gift shop is also expensive. There's great, cheap diners all around the hotel, like the cafe at the Edison hotel across the street, or the Evergreen Diner down on 47th. There is a fitness center that is open 24 hrs, I've never used it, but it looks nice from what I've seen. There's also a business center with high speed internet and all other business needs. There's also nice, efficient self service kiosks in the lobby and on the ground floor that you can print your boarding pass out on for free. I think you can also check out on the same kiosk. I'm used to the elevator system, so it didn't bother me. I did see people get confused with it easily though, like just getting in and looking for the buttons. The buttons aren't inside the cars, you press a key panel outside and it directs you to an elevator based on what floor your going to. The lobby is on the 8th floor. I never really had to wait too long for one, I think the slowest it was was when I was trying to get down one time from the 41st floor. You do have to sometimes press the button again. I'll admit I enjoy the elevators where you can see out, it's fun to look out and see the floors as you go buy, and it does move fast and going down, especially from the high floors, your ears may pop! One thing they've added in the elevators since my stay last year was a little TV showing news, weather etc... My first night, at about 3:30 AM, I heard a noise out in the hallway that I still have no idea what it was, and two people talking, it eventually stopped, but I didn't know what it was. It wasn't the fire alarm, I know that much. It was kind of annoying as it woke me up and continued on for some time. I also found a used washcloth between the bed and the one bedside table, it definitely wasn't mine. I don't know how long it had been there, but it was obviously something housekeeping didn't pick up. I also don't know if it was because of the high floor or what, but the water pressure in my bathroom was horrible. The shower was horrible, and practically everytime I flushed the toilet I had to flush it twice because the first time it wouldn't work. It never ran over or anything, thankfully, and it was loud when it did flush, it was just annoying to have to almost everytime flush it twice. This was the first time I had ever had problems like this with the bathroom at this hotel. I had a decent rate, not the best one I've had here, but cheaper than other hotels I priced. I got the best available rate, which has been cheaper in the past for the same time of year. This year there didn't seem to be any good rates for the time of my stay through Marriott Rewards. Overall, my stay was fine, and I will return, as I love the hotel!

Aug 23 2008 	Marriott Marquis a disappointment	My husband and I stayed there for 3 nights from Aug 17 to 20. Aug 17 2008 	Marriott Marquis Times Square -Great Location for Tourists	I spent 2 nights this past week at the Marquis. I was in NYC for a training and spent a Wednesday & Thursday night. I got a government rate due to my job so my rate was significantly cheaper than the going rate and I booked directly through Marriott.com.I took Amtrak in to Penn Station and I am pretty comfortable traveling around NYC so I took the subway, 1 stop to Times Square and then a couple block walk to the hotel. The check-in desk in on the 8th floor which was a bit odd, but no big deal. Check-in was far and away the worst part of the whole stay. 3 clerks were working when I arrived, each was busy. A line formed behind me as we waited for our turn. 2 of the 3 clerks were dealing with different problems with the guests. The 3rd clerk finally finished with their guest and told us to wait for someone else, and he walked away. That was really annoying. I proceeded to wait a total of 15 minutes before I was checked in. Too long to wait at 8pm at night after traveling and with luggage. (Frankly, too long to wait any time of the day!) The clerk who checked me in did not impress me with his customer service, but I wouldn't call him rude.My room was on the 39th floor, 2 Queen Sized beds. The elevator was a little slow for me since I was on one of the top floors. Someone has to stay on those floors, though-right? My room was impecably clean. The bath products were Bath & Body Works. There were 4 fluffy towels in my room. There was also a coffee maker which I didn't use.Large flat screen LCD TV was great, got most channels I wanted except no Food Network or Comedy Central. Oh well, not there to watch TV but they are basic cable channels so I was disappointed. The view was of Times Square and I didn't even shut the black out curtains at night. The view was great and the lights did not bother me at all.The bed was comfortable, the pillows were a little bit mushy for my taste, but workable. There was an i-Pod docking station/alarm clock which I thought was a nice touch.The internet was WIRED and cost $16.95/day-at least it should have been wireless at that price! What a rip-off. And it goes noon to noon not 24 hours from when you purchase. I was NOT impressed with that. I like to sit on my bed and do work when I travel as many others do, but that wasn't possible with wired access. I was able to pull it close enough to put my feet up on a bed but that was it. The connection speed was mediocre at best. Again for the price it should have been much better. So that was a little disappointing.The AC was fine, I like the room pretty cool so it was hard for me to tell if the AC wasn't working well or it was me. The room was around 67 the whole time, I would have preferred 65.With my TV on I couldn't hear anyone else in surrounding rooms. There is a Starbucks on the 8th and 1st floors of this hotel as well as numerous restaurants. For $10 I was able to eat a decent Starbucks breakfast each day of my stay as compared to the hotel restaraunt buffet at $28pp plus tax and gratuity. (Welcome to New York my friends!) The cheapest thing on the a la carte breakfast menu was a $10 fruit cup! So Starbucks it is! The room service menu was as expensive as can be expected, but you are in NYC, in an expensive hotel and in the middle of Times Square. Jul 23 2008 	The best	What a great hotel. We stayed here July 14th-17th as a surprise for my daughter who turned 16 the day we arrived. It was everything we were looking for. Jul 23 2008 	Another Great Review of the Marquis	I picked this hotel after reading the great reviews here because I thought it would be more memorable for my 10-year-olds first visit to NYC. I already knew the lobby was on the 8th floor and read how to use the elevators so we were out of our car and checked in our room in 10 minutes. I dont understand how anyone can complain about the elevators  we never waited more than a minute and we were told the hotel was at full capacity. As has been previously stated, you enter the floor you want to go to and it directs you to the appropriate elevator. It works brilliantly.We were on the 19th floor with a great view of Time Square (didnt pay extra). When we travel with our kids, we usually get a suite but our double/double room was very comfortable for the 4 of us. We had two comfy double beds and my husband and I slept with one child each very comfortably. There was a large flat-screen HDTV, a large desk for the laptop and two easy chairs w/ table by the large windows. The tub in the bathroom was huge  I love to take a good bath and this was very comfortable. The room set-up is nice because the bath and closet are separated from the main room so you can change privately, etc. We were amazed at how quiet it was  did not hear any hotel noise from neighbors or in the hallway. Its a huge hotel but it never felt crowded. I didnt notice much security in the lobby and wonder how they keep people out. If I was traveling alone, I might not like this place but it was fine for this trip with family. My husband used the health club both days and said it was amazing. He saw Manny Ramirez of the Boston Red Sox working out which made his day.We knew there was no overpriced mini-bar frig but the room had a nice ice bucket and we kept it filled with ice and sodas/water. You can rent a frig if you want. There is one of those single-cup coffee machines in the roof but I went down to Starbucks (2 onsite) or to the over-priced gift store where you can buy a $2.50 sodait is NYC so you cant let that stuff get to you. There are several grocery stores around the corner on 8th Ave.The foot traffic was typically crazy in Time Square so we often took 8th Ave to avoid the crowds. Central Park was an easy 15-minute walk, Rockefeller Center is 5 minutes and the Empire State 15-20-minute walk. We felt the Central Park Zoo and Amusement Center were over-rated but the kids loved the playgrounds. The location was central to most everything we wanted to do. Checking out was a breeze. Jul 20 2008 	Definetly a hotel for tourists in the big apple!	We booked this hotel after leaving the Jumeirah Essex hotel wanting to stay 1/2 of the time near Central Park and 1/2 near Times Square. Starbucks is in the hotel which, believe me, is an easier way of getting coffee than finding a place in Times Square. You push which floor you want and then it tells you alphabetically which elevator to get on. Time Square is really busy if you like crowds and the Marriott Marquis is in the middle of it. Jul 12 2008 	Magic at the Marquis	I have just returned from a 5 night stay at the Marriott Marquis with my family which includes fifty somethings and 18-21 year olds and would thoroughly recommend it as the perfect place to stay for the first time visitor to New York. We all loved the location, comfort and sheer luxury of this hotel. The location, right in the middle of the Times Square area, was ideal for walking to the nearer must-see tourist attractions, such as the Empire State Building, Grand Central Station, Macy's, the Rockefeller Centre, Central Park and Broadway shows. It was also a dropping off point for the open-toppped tour buses when you want to go further afield. We made full use of a 2 day pass on the Grayline buses to explore Chinatown, Little Italy, Greenwich Village, Harlem, Brooklyn and the Seaport district. One of the highlights of our visit was the night tour - the view of the Manhattan skyline and the bridges at dusk was sheer magic! The hotel also impressed us with the clean, comfortable and spacious rooms and the helpfulness of all the staff we encountered. From the people on the ground floor who arranged the luggage and taxis to the courteous receptionist who organised 3 rooms close together with good views to the chambermaids and waitresses who looked after our needs after exhausting days sightseeing everyone was polite and friendly (and we found the tipping system easy to manage, no-one seemed to expect huge amounts).The elevator system worked well for us, we never waited more than about 30 seconds even on peak times and the views were great.One point - I have seen many tourists asking about taxis and airport transport - we were a party of 5 adults and had no problems in getting a yellow cab to and from JFK at a set rate of 45 dollars + toll and tip. The hotel organised this when we left and also stored our bags for the day as we had an evening flight.We enjoyed a visit to the View restaurant at the top of the hotel - about 8-9 is best to get a full revolution and see the lights come on and the sunset over NY. This, plus walking the Brooklyn Bridge and the night bus tour were our favourite memories of our trip - New York at all levels! We would all love to return, preferably in December to see the city in a different season and would definitely stay at the Marquis again. Hope this review is helpful and enjoy your holiday as much as we did!

Jul 11 2008 	A pleasant stay in the heart of Times Square	We stayed at the New York Marriott Marquis for three nights over a recent (busy) weekend in New York (in fact, the hotel was sold out one of the nights, no small feat for such a huge facility). We had also considered the Renaissance Times Square, but ended up pleased with our choice.First of all, the hotel is literally in the middle of Times Square, which has its pluses and minuses. On the positive side, nothing can beat the scene--or the view from many of the rooms--of the flashing neon and people. Times Square is an excellent location for tourists because its the middle of the city, with easy access to most subway lines that can take you downtown or uptown. A cab ride to Greenwich Village was about 10-12 minutes.On the negative side, the rush of the crowd right outside the doors does get to be a bit overwhelming and annoying--you've really got to fight your way just to get back to the hotel, even late at night. But for the purposes of our trip, which was a nice getaway (without the kid) for the weekend, it served us well.The hotel itself is rather stunning inside due to the large atrium. Considering the size of the place, most things are efficient--the high tech elevator system works very well, check in moves quickly.Room quality itself actually exceeded my expections. We were placed on the 30th floor (concierge level) with a king room facing the north side of Times Square. The size of the room was about standard for a hotel, which is above average for New York City. The furniture was new and in good condition. There was a 40 inch LG LCD tv. Sofa and bed were all in good shape. The bathroom was not spectacular but the shower was modern. The room had floor to ceiing windows to showcase the view.There were two negatives about the room. The first was a rather musty sort of smell that was vaguely of smoke--now the whole hotel is smoke free. It wasn't overpowering or awful, and I do have a particularly sensitive nose for these things, but I nonetheless noted it. I ended up not changing rooms because we liked the location of it and everything else was fine, but I did give it some consideration.The second negative was light from the atrium (interior) side. The room was remarkably quiet given the location--exterior noise was highly muffled, and even the rooms themselves were unusually quiet for a hotel like this. There was, however, a great deal of light coming in from under the door which made the room rather bright. Now putting something by the door would easily take care of this, but I noted it anyway.Also note that there are no vending machines--however, complimentary water bottles are in the bathrooms. The maid service was unusually good---the room was very thoroughly cleaned each day. There was also turndown service, and all towels were replaced (we took showers in the afternoon after a morning of touring NYC) which was a nice touch.Overall, I would certainly recommend this hotel. Jul 11 2008 	Awesome!!!	I stayed at the Marriott June 30 - July 5. It was an awesome experiences. The rooms are larger than the Ritz hotels I've stayed at and the beds are even larger. Jul 6 2008 	Seamless stay over holiday weekend	First of all, let me preface this by saying that I come to New York at least once a year for vacation. Jun 17 2008 	Another good review	Just spent 4 nights at the Marriott Marquis and have nothing special to add to the other happy campers. It is a fabulous hotel, very large rooms, absolutely no problem with elevator delays, maybe those reviewers didn't know how to use the keypad. The longest we waited (twice in four days) was 2 or 3 minutes. Most times an elevator arrived in less than 20 seconds. Friendly, courteous staff, spotlessly clean, nice bedding and toiletries. We were part of a business group, and several of those who tried the hotel food were not impressed, especially the breakfast. We didn't eat in the hotel so can't offer our personal opinion. The table service in the Atrium Lounge (bar) was deadly slow, though. Fantastic location if you like being in the Times Square action, we were on Floor 17 and could still hear the sirens, horns, etc, but not enough to keep us awake. If you are planning to visit the Guggenheim, wait until after June 27th. The outside AND inside is under construction for a special exhibit and there are only 2 small side galleries open, not worth looking at.We had good food at Bond 45 (at Broadway & 45th), at Connolly's Pub (ditto), good super-fast breakfast at Cafe Edison (inside Hotel Edison on 46th & Broadway, I think) -- the best oatmeal I ever had anywhere and good pancakes or waffles. Stay away from their eggs and ham, though. You can skip Junior's Bakery right across from the hotel -- both the take-out pastries and sit-down breakfasts were disappointing and not worth the hype. The best meal we had was at The Cancun Mexican Restaurant on 8th Ave between 56th & 55th. Killer frozen margaritas too!If you take the subway, especially down to WTC and Financial District, be sure to ask the booth attendant which train to take. The stop we wanted was closed for construction and we ended up in Brooklyn. The last time we were in NYC was over 20 years ago, and I have to tip my hat to ex-Mayor Rudy Guliani. The difference is amazing. First of all, the people are much friendlier and open than they were before, very proud of their city and happy to direct and offer tips to tourists. There are police EVERYWHERE! We felt absolutely safe. And the city streets are amazingly clean. I can't wait to go back and do the things we didn't have time for on this trip.The hop on/hop off bus is worth the money. If you want a fun NYC experience, take one of those bicycle rickshaws and hang on!

Jun 13 2008 	Amazing Hotel	I have been to New York before but this was the first time I stayed at the Marquis. Jun 7 2008 	King of Times Square	I have no idea how anyone could rate this hotel as anything except 4 or 5 unless one is expecting something unreal. The Marriott Marquis is a giant hotel right on Times Square. People are everywhere, duh!!! But so are great restaurants, delis, theaters, and shopping---all within ten casual minutes by foot. Buy an unlimited MetroCard for $24 and you get seven days of unlimited subway and bus. One of the major transportatiojn hubs is on 42nd and Broadway, which is 5 minutes away if you walk slowly. BTW, the subway system is fantastic---fast, frequent, clean, and goes virtually everywhere. The maligned elevator system is actually marvelous. Never had to wait more than a couple of minutes. EVER. Two Starbucks on the premises, a huge atrium and lounge to enjoy your coffee or drink and a Junior's Bakery across the street for fancier pastries and "New York's Best Cheesecake." BTW, TKTS (which is the discount outlet for that evening's Broadway shows) is currently at the Marriott while their permanent office is being renovated across the street. Another perk! Here's a tip--if you like Chinese food, NY's Chinatown is quite good and the cheapest of any large city I have ever visited.If this sounds like a NYC fan talking, it is, but prior to this visit...not so much. I was fully prepared to dislike the city but could not. NYC just plain WORKS and other cities like San Francisco in particular could learn a lot from the Big Apple. We stayed for eight days and every day was chock full of activities and sights---the Metropolitan Museum of Art being a close second only to the Louvre in the world, IMHO. Back to the Marquis...asked for and got a TSq view on the 33rd floor. Beds OK, bath fine and the space very generous by NY standards. Concierges could be a little more helpful but with 2000 rooms, they are overwhelmed on occasion. Never heard outside noise from the street but did occasionally hear doors and drawers slamming next door. Arrived at 9:00 am from SF on the redeye and immediately were allowed to check in! Then on departure, we requested late checkout (another redeye flight) and stayed until 1:00pm. Great service, I'd say. In summary, this hotel is PERFECT for the first time NYC visitor and for everyone wanting to be in the middle of the party.

Everything in this hotel has just a very cheap appearance, from carpets over cabinets to bathrooms - not to talk about the ceilings in the guestrooms. The corridors look like in a youth hostel, the check-in service feels like the one of a low-budget airline, the restaurant for breakfast creates the permanent desire to finish as quickly as possible... and many more things that are not worth spending my time with.IN SUMMARY: if you like to look at nice things and want to feel good when staying away from home: DO NOT STAY HERE. I certainly will never return to this property.

Apr 27 2008	Elevators still drag down the quality of this hotel	This was my third stay at the Marriott Marquis. On prior stays, it was the in-house parking which swayed our choice. Apr 27 2008 	Crazy elevators	My wife and I stayed at the Marriott Marquis for three nights prior to starting a cruise from New York.On arrival there was not a porter in sight and no-one to give us any idea where the main reception area was. And wait ..... and wait . !! Some guests told us that they had to wait anything up to 20 minutes on occasions. My wife concluded that the system had been programmed by an IT engineer with a grudge against humanity. So having got to the Reception desk our faith was restored. Check-in was swift and courteous, and our luggage was whisked away by an efficient Bell Captain who took us to our room on the 45th floor (as high as the guest rooms go) and made sure that we had settled in OK.Guest rooms are arranged around a vast central open space that extends from the 8th to the 45th floors. Mar 23 2008 	Don't Spend Your Own Money!	This is a great hotel, if you're staying on somebody else's dollar. It's got everything you want - for a price. If you can afford it, go for it. The location is in the heart of Times Square, so all prices are inflated, but the Marriott Marquis assumes most of its guests are business travelers and can spend money like water. I stayed there because of a business convention, so I fit their profile. Want to use a computer at the hotel's business center? $32 per hour. Have a glass of wine in the bar? $13 or more. (In fact, the wine list includes one wine I often buy at home for $8.99 a bottle. They charge $48 for the same bottle.) Yet they refused to honor the credit card I tried to check in with, because it had the name of my company on it, even though they had accepted it to guarantee my reservation. I was forced to use a personal credit card. They can afford to have that attitude because there's a demand for high end service in that location. Honestly, though, I've stayed in lots of of hotels just as good and with a nicer attitude, but at half the price. I'll stay here again next year ... but only if my employer is paying the bill. Next time I'm in NYC (in about three months) I'll stay elsewhere, where the prices are rational and the people are friendlier -- because it will be MY money.

Mar 18 2008 	Typical Marriott. Great location typical accommodations.	First, let me say that I am a Marriott employee. I love the company's hotels and accommodations. Every time I stay at a Marriott, the service is the same: friendly and helpful. Having said that, the Marriott Marquis Times Square New York lives up to the expected Marriott service level, but isn't really anything more than the typical Marriott property. In fact, there are more comfortable Marriott hotels around the country than the Marquis. What you get at this particular hotel, however, is the location. It is perfectly located in Times Square on Broadway between 46th and 47th.It is expensive to stay at the Marquis, although I got a discount for being an employee. The first floor lobby isn't really the lobby. You have to go up to the 8th floor to check in. Weird, huh? There are a bunch of high speed elevators in a circle that take you up through the hotel, but you might wait a while because there are so many people going up and down. The room was a typical king standard room. I had a partial view of Broadway and a lovely view of an office building. The bed was comfortable, but not nearly as much as some of the other Marriott properties I've stayed at . I don't think this room was equipped with the new Revive bedding that can be found at many other Marriott properties. The bed is why I love staying at Marriott's, and this one wasn't as good as the others. The plasma TV was very nice though, and the channel list included HD channels.As I said, the location was great. It was wonderful coming back from seeing a broadway show and walking to our hotel, in the midst of the throngs of people. I always wanted to be one of those people who could just veer off the path and walk into the hotel. I must say, it was wonderful. The hotel was quiet, once you're in your room, and the accommodations were comfortable. The prices for everything were ridiculous, of course, since you're in Times Square, but what else do you expect? Overall, the hotel was a typical Marriott. Nice design, great location, comfortable room and friendly staff, but nothing spectacular. The best part was being in Times Square.

Mar 1 2008 	An experience in itself	For those who are looking to visit New York City for a day or two, this hotel cannot be beat. There are many things that make the Marriott Marquis the greatest hotel in Times Square, but the #1 by far is the location. It is located directly in the dead center of Times Square, making basically everything in short walking distance. The hotel features an incredibly convenient and smart elevator system which makes getting to your room in a hotel with an incredible number of rooms an easy process. On the main floor area there is a very lovely sushi restaurant, and a complete bar area with a wide range of exotic drinks and a glass-wall intimate-table-seating area that directly overlooks Times Square, giving you a view of the nightlife while chatting with friends. All rooms also overlook Times Square, so a great view is never too far away from you. For those of you who are musical theater enthusiasts, the hotel offers a ticket booth where you can inquire about showtimes, locations, even buy tickets right there at the hotel (though with a rather high service charge). Also, the Marquis plays host to "The Drowsy Chaperone" itself. Service was excellent, we requested a rollaway bed for our room which was promptly delivered, and the staff was always ready to answer any questions we had. Parking was valet, and convenient in every way. The hotel also offers a huge exercise facility, but we didn't get the opportunity to use it. I should mention that this hotel is a great idea for a short-term trip, since the rooms are quite expensive. For a longer stay in New York, I imagine there are more affordable locations, but for a short-term, amazing experience, the Marquis isn't just a place to stay, it will become a memorable part of your experience altogether. (I recently visited NYC again, and even though I didn't stay AT the Marquis, I still went there just for the bar and restaurant!)

Feb 9 2008 	Fabulous fabulous experience	Our family stayed at the Marriott Marquis for two nights to celebrate my husband's 50th birthday. We will NEVER forget this trip!We drove up from Maryland in a driving rainstorm and were exhausted when we arrived. Just before we arrived, a host from The View Restaurant called on my cell phone to confirm our reservations for dinner that night. He assured me that we would have a window table, and wished my husband 'Happy Birthday'.The valet parking attendant and bellman greeted us right away, helped our girls (7 and 10) fold their blanket and promptly whisked our car and luggage away, with smiles, directions to the lobby, small talk to our daughters and understated efficiency.We entered the hotel and were totally awed! It was beautiful and busy. The elevators zooming up and down (our girls compared them to the vacuum chutes used by drive-in banks to send transactions to your car) with the different colored lights on each were a sight to behold!The concierge at the desk directed us to the elevator pad, and the adventure began. The elevators are on a sort of reservation system: You press the floor you are requesting on the pad, and a letter appears, telling you to go to that specific elevator - how cool is that? The girls worked out a system as to when each would have a turn to 'call the elevator'.We arrived on the 8th floor, which is comprised of the lobby of the hotel, several restaurants, a concierge desk, a bell desk, lounges, gift shop and travel offices (American Express, Ticket offices, etc.). We arrived at 3:35, and waited in line for about 5 minutes to check in. Our girls sat on a bench near the elevators with their necks craned because the elevator bank is a huge circular structure in the middle of the hotel. All rooms are situated on the outside of the 'hallway' and the inside of the hallway gives a view all the way down to the first floor or all the way up to the 47th floor. Our older daughter told my husband that she could go home now, she was so amazed!While checking in, the reservations agent asked our business there, and I told her it was my husband's birthday. She immediately gave us a voucher for free breakfast buffet (up to $60) at the Atrium Lounge!? Amazing! We had a Times Square View room (towards Central Park) on the 32nd floor. It looked like we could reach out and touch the ginormous billboards outside when we opened our curtains! Our luggage arrived within 15 minutes of our arriving at our room and the bellhop took the time to orient us to where we were, pointed out M&M World to us, told us that the Minskoff Theatre was directly across the street (we saw 'The Lion King' matinee the next day) and told us about all of the amenities of the hotel.We just walked around the lobby and gawked (there were several conventions there, but we never felt rushed or crowded). We dressed for dinner and took the elevator down to the 2nd floor to get the express elevator to the 47th floor. The View Restaurant was exquisitely wonderful, on Friday night! The prices were exactly what we'd expect for the service, food quality, view and experience. For a prie fixe of $67.50 per meal (the girls split their meal), we ate WELL - and my husband had several wait staff sing 'Happy Birthday!' to him - BY NAME, to the total delight of our girls!Breakfast at the Atrium Lounge on Saturday morning at 9:30 am was beyond yummy - fabulous service, excellent selections and variety, great omelettes made to order and freshly made waffles and pancakes brought to your table! Oh, My!We had room service for 4 for dinner (after the play and a bicycle rickshaw ride around Central Park), and our food was delivered within 25 minutes of ordering - on a Saturday night?!Overall, we have traveled the world - with and without children - our experience at the Marriott Marquis was one in a lifetime! We are already planning our next trip there! Go Marriott!!!

Feb 6 2008 	Personal and Business perspective review	I have stayed at this hotel over 15 times for business and once, my last trip for a personal trip. My fiancee is from Kansas and his best friend and wife flew in to celebrate his birthday. They had never seen NY so I used Marriot points to book us a weekend at the Marquis. The main plus of this hotel is location. It sits in the heart of Time Square and most rooms have a fabulous view. For those not familiar with Manhattan it is in Midtown meaning it is centrally located on the island.The bad: The parking attendants are clearly not trained in the "Marriot way" and you can expect to find a "lot full" sign posted if you are checking in on a Friday or Sat. They are experts in the NY way, which means be prepared to pay. Tip $20 bucks and a parking spot magically appears. Marriot really has to fix this as it's hurting their reputation. Full should really mean full especially when it costs $50 bucks a night already to park your beloved vehicle. I saw the parking attendants turn away an elderly couple who had driven from Canada telling them the lot was full and that they had to find another lot. It was shameful. Sending these elderly people out into a city they clearly did not know to find a garage that was 10 blocks away. They didn't even take their baggage and hold it for them.My other gripe is the Japanese restaurant in the lobby (8th floor). It is just awful if you want sushi. I took our friends from Kansas there our first night and the fish was not tasteful and the avocado was brown....ugh. If you must eat there order the steak. The waitstaff is pretty bad too. There are a million fabulous places to eat in NY, go find em!Marriot classifies this as a category 7 hotel but I really think only the location makes it a 7. The carpet is just hideous and the rooms could use redecorating. The good: Especially if you have friends or clients from out of town go sit in the lobby bar and you will find the whole side of the bar is a glass wall that overlooks times square. The drinks are pricey but worth it for the view. Also, if money is not a concern eat in the restaurant on the top floor that rotates. It's excellent and worth it. The check in staff have always been helpful and will generally give you times square view for no extra charge if you ask nicely. The maid service is always good and the concierge is not terribly friendly but then again you are in NY. She does her job but does not go above and beyond. Do you your own research and get the maps from her. The gym is good for those weary business folks that need a work out. Keep in mind there is no pool though. The business center is well run and efficient. **One tip for everyone about the elevators**When you walk in on the first floor you will see a bank of elevators labeled alphabetically A,B,C and so on. You will also see a key pad mounted to the wall at the front of the bank of elevators. You must type in what floor you want to go to before you board an elevator. The keypad will tell you which elevator is going to your floor. For instance you need to check in so you need the 8th floor. Type in 8 and the keypad will blink a letter like "J". Board the elevator labeled J and it will automatically go to the 8th floor. There are no buttons on the inside of any of the elevators. It all runs off the keypad by computer. If board any old elevator you will have the pleasure of going where everyone else needs to go. Just a tip! I can't tell you how many people I have seen dash for an elevator only to get inside and look dumbfounded when there are no buttons to push. Enjoy!

Jan 12 2008 	New Years Eve at the Marriott Marquis	If you are going to go to New York's Times Square for New Years Eve then THIS is the hotel to stay in. The hotel lounge on the 8th floor is a great place to relax while watching the goings-on in the Square and the View lounge on the 49th floor has superb views of the city. Location-wise, as can be imagined, it is right on Broadway for the theatres and within a short walk of Central Park to the north and Soho/Greenwich to the south. Jan 7 2008 	Wow ! - Times Square On New Year's Eve	My first ever visit to New York was spent at the Marriot Marquis.This was a "special occasion" family break between 29/12/2007 and 2/1/2008 so we were here for New Year.We had asked for a low floor with connecting rooms and these were duly waiting for us on the 16th floor.The rooms were luxurious and huge with fantastic comfortable beds.Everyone from the porters to all of the staff were incredibly helpful.The hotel is very central for sightseeing and although busy did not feel that way.The highlight had to be New Year's Eve.All guests were warned that unless you were in Times Square very early that it would be impossible to see anything if you arrived later on.However we didn't manage down until nearly 10.30pm and resigned ourselves to the fact that although we could hear the festivities that we wouldn't see them.Anyway I found a very helpful porter and after I explained to him that this was a " one off " experience he managed to get us into the Square (for a small fee !!!). Dec 27 2007 	Guess we went on a bad week????	I am confused on the reviews here. After our stay, I was sure to come here and find bad reviews. We went for five days the week prior to Christmas and here is what we experienced. We checked in around noon and were told we could check in and get a lower level room on the 8th floor, or wait and get one on the 49th. We decided to wait four hours and get a higher room. After checking our bags in and walking around the city in our traveling clothes (from Tampa, FL) we returned to find they were giving us the room on the 8th floor. After speaking w/ management we were offered on on the 34th which was fine. The room was a nice size- a little larger than the standard. The bed was VERY comfortable, but there was a layer of dust on the back of the toilet and the tissue box was disgusting. It had toothpaste spray all over the side and dust all over the top. YUCK! My husband always checks the waters b/c we have been charged many times for the person before us opening them and filling w/ tap water. Of course, this had already been done (ALWAYS CHECK THIS!) and we called the front desk immediately so we would not be charged. We left the room and came back two hours later which is when the guy had JUST come to the room to replace the waters. When we rec'd our bill days later, we were charged for the waters we called about! However, it was taken off our bill with a simple visit to the front desk. We were also charged a $15 room service fee for the guy to bring us new ones.The location was excellent w/ the subway close and all shows and good food close. I HIGHLY recomment John's pizza around the corner in the old church- yummy!Concierge was hit or miss. I would either get someone extremely informative and polite, or I got an attitude that they thought they were better than me and how dare I ask them a question. There was a spanish girl w/ med lenght hair that was polite every single time and remembered me. And I always tipped.I also noticed they do not answer the phone with "Good evening Mr. Kilpatrick how may I help you?" as they did years ago. I missed that and thought it gave it a personal touch.The View is awesome but be careful. I ordered the buffet late one night. It is $20 and within minutes, bus boys ran up and grabbed my plates!!!! I guess they were closing which I wish my waiter expressed to me before I paid $20 for two bites!The elevators were slammed on Sat. and Sun. which is understandable.All in all I will stay somewhere else next time. I'm not sure if they got new management or what but it has gone down hill from a few years ago.

Good Solid Hotel	Just returned from a 5 night stay at the Omni Berkshire. There were 3 of us in total. We had booked at the beginning of the year so there really was no excuse. Im not happy with put up beds  when you pay for a nice hotel you expect a proper bed to sleep on. The 1st room we were given was so small  we just couldnt figure out where the put up bed would go as it was so small so we asked to be moved to a larger room  we were given a larger room and I was impressed with the swiftness of this however really on arrival we should have been given this originally.The concierge were the best thing about the hotel  so incredibly helpful and full of knowledge. Everyone in the hotel was friendly. We had dinner in the restaurant  very good quality. The resturant manager was very professional and friendly.The hotel and room was very very clean. Location wise it was excellent  it was just by Cartier on 5th Avenue  so a short walk to central park  and very need a tube station.One thing I must say is that on arrival  they demanded taking approximately $50 per day for a charge against the room in case we charged anything to the room. Most odd. I have stayed at many many hotels and not once have I ever encountered this. We will await this back on to our card  they did say itd take 3 business days  so we shall see! We did say that we wouldnt be charging to the room and if we did we would be paying immediately by cash.The meat packing district is good for bars, clubs and resturants.We had dinner at the Plaza and also on a different day - lunch. Both were lovely.The hotel is very nice. I would consider staying again.

Nov 9 2009 	you guys suck [--]	please no one stay here!! horrible horrible the hotel blamed everything on their renovation that is going to take place in dec and jan... we were staying for 4 days didnt want to give us 2 double beds til i complained about asking for a roll away 3x but never got it. then we had no electric socket in the room 3 different department by fone call said it was in the bathroom they never believed us when we said there wasnt one til we got an engineeer to prove to them we didnt have one then they gave us attitude! i was shocked at the attitude we were given. only half nice person there was the lady who checked us in it was 7am we were exhausted from our trip from the west coast! but she had to give us a lecture on how she'd normally charge us for checking in early BUT she wont this time and how she would charge us for a rollaway BUT she wont this time... even tho i asked for 2 doubles and she said they were sold out of 2 doubles! i wrote to their corporate i am still waiting for a response... their turndown service was a joke left dirty linen in our room then manager said she was having a " hard day and had lots of things on her mind" i sympathized but why would the manager tell me that? only nice thing to say about this hotel was the location! finally one GREAT THING! Oct 23 2009 	Great location good bar and good perks with Select Guest membership	Stayed for 5 nights at this hotel with my girlfriend. Oct 7 2009	The Omni has won me over	I stayed at the Omni for a long weekend girls getaway trip with my mom and I couldn't be happier with my experience. I was bummed out that I was unable to stay at either of my favorite hotel chains (The Fairmont or The Ritz Carlton) because it was a last minute trip and the rates at these properties were about $1,000.00 per night! Since I always stay at either property if available wherever my travels take me, I wasn't expecting much from the Omni because I paid a lot less and I've always thought that there is really no comparison when it comes to service and quality for either of my favorite hotels. But I was proved wrong immediately upon my arrival at 10:30 am...not only was my room ready, they gave me a large, quiet room, on a high floor, away from the elevator, with extra pillows, just as I had requested when I booked my reservation. Their Select Guest Program works wonderful. I loved getting my complimentary beverages & paper in the morning. The room was spacious, nicely furnished, and clean. The bathroom was a replica of what I have seen in a number the Ritz Carlton's rooms, large all marble with a Jacuzzi and separate shower, lots of counter space, lighted mirror etc... Not the typical (closet size) bathrooms that others complain about in NYC. The service was also very efficient & courteous. The only things I would change....the furnishings & TV, although nice they need to be replaced, you can see the wear and tear and doesnt everyone have a flat screen these days? Over all I would recommend this place to those who are hesitant because of the bad reviews, I definitely plan on returning to this property, the area is of course wonderful with all the best and most exclusive shops all around you, the subway is a couple of blocks away, plenty of cabs around if you prefer to take them & you don't see the typical "dirty city" aspects around. There were plenty of police officers around the area, so safety was not an issue. We didn't see a single beggar in the vicinity not until we left the area and went down to lower Manhattan or near the parks. If youre on a budget then this is not your place or area to visit, otherwise enjoy what the hotel has to offer the hotels restaurant was delicious too.

Oct 4 2009 	Great location to explore NYC	We took the Airtrain and then the subway from JFK to the hotel ($7.25) - the nearest station was on 53rd Street. We would stay here again based on our experience.

Sep 15 2009 	Nice place... good location	My husband and I took a trip to New York to celebrate his big birthday! We got a great deal on the lowcostnewyork wesbite to stay at Omni Berkshire Place that cost about half the price of the Omni hotel's own website. We took the airtrain and subway from JFK airport to NY which was quick and easy, and very cheap at $7.25 each! The subway was right near to the hotel and we had no problem getting there with our cases. Check-in was quick and easy. I also signed up online for the select guest programme so gave my membership number at check-in to allow us the free wi-fi in our room, free newspaper and complimentary morning drinks. Really worth signing up for - you get 2 drinks each every morning and can choose from tea, coffee, hot choc, juices, cola & bottled water which was really worthwhile.. do not leave home without signing up for this! Take a laptop too as the wi-fi is really useful for planning your days and in particular for us allowed us to check-in online with Virgin for our flight home.We were in room 835.... we did expect the most basic room as we got such a good rate so we were not suprised by the poor view of a building site but I'm sure others who had paid a lot more than us would have been very disappointed. The noise was pretty bad during the day and on our first morning, we were woken up at 6am by the construction noise which was a shame, but as we were in New York, we just got ourselves up and out to enjoy the city. The room was a really good size with a huge bed & big bathroom. We did get a king bed and non-smoking room as requested which was nice. As in other reviews, the hotel is a little dated - eg furniture and old style TV but if you are there to see NY then the hotel is fine... we have stayed in other hotels with much much smaller rooms.The hotel is in a good location - close by to walk to fith avenue, times square, grand central station, central park, rockerfeller center & top of the rock, st patricks cathedral.... need I go on... and if you wanted to venture further afield, the subway was very close to the hotel and for $7.25 you could buy a one day fun pass to venture around the city. The hotel was extrememly clean and our room was cleaned every day... with a turndown service at night which also provided you with ice which was a nice touch! Check out was again quick and easy and nice at 12 noon. We were able to leave our cases with the bellmen as our flight was not till the evening so we could go off and do some last minute sightseeing and shopping. We were delayed a little when returning to collect our cases which was a shame as there didn't seem to be enough staff on hand to collect everyone's cases but when we were seen to the man was polite and quick to get our case.All in all a nice hotel that I would recommend, but probably not at the prices on the hotel's website... definitely look at other websites first.

Sep 12 2009 	Lots of annoyances at a good hotel	I've now stayed at this hotel two times. My first stay, two years ago, was much better than my last. The Omni's convenient location could not overcome the numerous small problems that I encountered during my recent stay.It all began at check-in. I arrived late at night because of weather delays, so I was hoping to go straight to bed. Unfortunately, the room I had been assigned had not been cleaned by housekeeping prior to my arrival. So, I headed back to the reception desk. The gentleman there apologized & gave me another room. This room was very nice & probably a little larger than the premier level room I had reserved. The room was clean and very comfortable. Unlike other guests, I had no noise issues whatsoever. I did, however, have other annoyances. The Omni Select Guest program gives members a complimentary morning beverage. You fill out a card & hang it on your door at night, then room service brings the beverage in the morning. At check-in, the clerk told me that unfortunately, they were out of the cards. I found this odd. The next morning, they still didn't have them. Finally in the afternoon, the cards arrived from somewhere. It may sound small or petty, but in the hospitality industry, little things mean a lot. The rest of my stay was thankfully uneventful. My involvement with the Omni did not end at check-out. When I checked my credit card balance a few days later, I noticed the charge on my account was more than my actual bill. After several calls to the hotel, the accounting department determined that I was charged for someone else's stay and they, in turn, were charged for my stay. I guess we checked in on the same day and had similar names. The whole thing was bizarre. At least they eventually figured out what happened and my card was credited for the difference. As an additional annoyance, Omni Select Guest has still not awarded my airline miles after almost a month. Overall, the hotel is nice, but the rooms are really showing their age. The staff is friendly and the location is great. The numerous annoyances I experienced, however, have led me to believe that I will search for a new hotel during my next stay in New York.

Aug 30 2009 	Fantastic Stay at the Omni	Every year, my friend and I meet for a girls' weekend in New York. We had stayed at the Omni a couple of years ago, and due to slight displeasure with the location of the room (near the elevator - noisy) and the thought that we should try something different, last year we stayed somewhere else. We found that the concierges at the other hotel were less knowledgeable and less connected than the ones at the Omni, and since as a Select Guest I got a special rate on a room at the Omni this year, we decided we'd give it another try. I also had a couple of free upgrade certificates that I had gotten in the past (and which had expired) but I thought I'd bring them along and ask if I could still use them. We were not disappointed. The smoke odor wasn't too bad, especially after opening some windows and getting some fresh air in there. (it's also nice to be able to open the windows). The deep bathtub was very comfortable, the rooms were huge, and the bed was very comfortable. Randy the Concierge was good as ever, and everyone at the hotel was friendly and helpful. We're looking forward to our next stay at the Omni! (ps, across the street is a restaurant called The Fig and Olive - it was really good too)

Aug 23 2009 	Excellent stay	When you check out a hotel, you are drawn to the negative reviews first. Well, I am so happy that we booked here. Aug 21 2009 	Couldn't believe how great the service was!	I went with friends for a weekend. There were four of us in an "upgraded" suite. Aug 19 2009 	We stay here whenever we are in NYC	We like everything about this hotel, except maybe the price but it is N.Y.C. and most prices are high there. Aug 14 2009 	They almost killed my son	This is the first message, but not the last. Four days before Christmas 2007 I checked my family into this hotel, booking the Madison Suite. Aug 10 2009 	Great location. Needs updating.	We booked this stay through a travel website offering a package on airfare and a hotel. The lobby is small but welcoming, the general areas are wearing well and don't feel as dated as the guest rooms feel. The view from the top of the hotel and the very nice health club are excellent. The king bed guest rooms do not leave much room for spreading out--but that isn't unusual for a hotel in NYC. The furnishings in the guest rooms we saw are showing their age (e.g. conventional tube television, bedspread rather than duvee cover, etc.). The bathroom is small but well done. The restaurant and bar are excellent. Last but not least the staff was excellent. Front desk and concierge were polite and accommodating. Aug 10 2009 	ok but not worth 4 stars more like 3	This hotel is in a good location but it is not the best Hotel in the area the New york Place which is about 2 minutes around the corner from the Omni is so much nicer and even less expensive than the Omni.The rooms in the Omni feel old fashioned and don't really look like the web site pictures. Jul 31 2009 	Great Location But That's About It	We were fine with a tiny room - even one facing construction as our view. After all, it is New York. Biggest problem with this was not having a view, but there was also a little bit of noise Friday morning that woke us up. There was no construction going on over the weekend.The room was nice in all aspects except for the small tube TV in the armoire. You would think a hotel this nice would have upgraded to a flat-screen TV by now! But we only watched the TV for weather updates and news at night. I also didn't like the "limpy" pillows that I had on my king bed.Location is great - 1 block from a few subway stations, and 2 blocks from Rockefeller Plaza.There was a street fair going on the Sunday morning we checked out, so it took over 45 mins to get our car out of the Valet. Jul 26 2009	OK NOT SUPERB	I travel a lot for work so I'm more picky than most hotel guests and for my money, the Omni is just ok. When we got back to the room late at night and saw what they delivered we were appalled. It was an old (1960's maybe?) metal cot with exposed springs that folds in half. Something your Aunt Ida would make you sleep on when you were a kid visiting. The mattress was so cheap and foamy soft, that it sagged horribly in the center when you laid on it. Classy! I ended up putting the mattress on the floor and the frame in the hallway for pickup. No one, I mean NO ONE could possibly sleep on this bed comfortably, even if they were 85 pounds. A word to the Omnni - it's 2009--buy some air mattresses and ditch the reform school bedding.The furnishings are a bit dated, too. a 19" tube TV and a 1980's radio/CD and CASSETTE minii boombox was set up plus a standard clock radio. Jun 23 2009 	good but not great	i booked two rooms via bidding on priceline and received reservations at the omni berkshire. after reading several reviews on trip advisor i was relieved to find that overall comments were positive. this hotel definitely is geared towards a family/older population. the concierge staff are nice but are older and good for information re. tourist things, but not nightlife. furthermore, the gym was quite impressive with fairly update cardio equipment and a small weight section . plus GREAT location in march (3 months before my trip) i completed the omni select guest form online to make known my preference of room (double beds) in addition to signing up for free wifi for each room,newspapers everyday and complimentary drinks in the morning, in addition to bottled water upon arrival. a week ahead of my trip i called to confirm that i had two double rooms booked. unfortunately, they were all booked up despite my request in march! i called several times before arriving in new york to see if they had any open double rooms. when i arrived at the hotel, the front desk staff was very helpful.. there was only one double room open.. so they upgraded the other room to a king and offered us a cot free of charge. despite signing up for the select guest... my group received 3 newspapers for the week, no water upon arrival and no complimentary beverages in the mornings.. we did get our wifi internet as requested... but you have to sign in with your user name and password each time you want to use it.. (got a bit annoying after a week..)the only other negative thing i have to say is that after we checked out and returned home, my friend was charged $1300 for her hotel fee despite us already prepaying via priceline. she was not given any receipt to acknowledge this charge and didn't recognize the mistake till she received her credit card statement. it took them about 4 days to correct

Jun 21 2009 	Lovely hotel lovely staff fabulous location	I stayed at the Omni Berkshire Place this weekend, more than 25 years after my first visit there. I also requested the concerige confirm a restaraunt reservation while we were out during the day, surprisingly this wasn't done for us despite me having written all the details down for them. Although on the last day the doormen were very friendly and helpful. Would I stay here again, no, this hotel is not a five star property, it's three star plus, as a result it is comparatively overpriced. It strong point is it's location, but this is New York, there are a number of better quality hotels in the vicinity. If you are visiting New York for a special occasion and want to stay somewhere to remember, then look elsewhere. If you're visiting with friends or a repeat visitor and just need a room, you could do worse but, you could do better.

Apr 14 2009 	Superb at the right price!	As a family of six we stayed at the Omni Berkshire Place in 3 Doubles for a week in April and had a brilliant time. The hotel is definately a 4* property with the service you would expect. Although it has about 250 rooms it feels like a much smaller hotel as each floor only has 35 rooms and there are plenty of lifts/elevators, and we could not fault any of the staff a single time, as everyone from doormen and receptionists to the housekeeping staff were excellent, and although all impeccably behaved, none had the prententious attitude you sometime get in luxury hotels - just plain friendly.The rooms were very large by NYC standards, even though we made our booking on Priceline and got our rooms at about half of the rate advertised on the hotels own website for the dates we stayed, and so were allocated standard rooms. We emailed in advance to ask for rooms as high up as possible, as traffic noise can be an issue at night in some NYC locations, and were given rooms on the 16th floor, which was great. If you pay $300 per night, you might expect something even better than us, and so should choose to stay in a 5* hotel like the Ritz Carlton or Mandarin Oriental.The decor is very old-world, and although incredibly well maintanied, the hotel shows it's age with extensive use of marble, old-fashioned ceiling cornice, brass everywhere and small lifts. So if you prefer your hotels Philippe Stark cool, this might not be the best choice for you.Being on the corner of Madison Avenue and 52nd street, 5th Avenue with all the high end shop is 30 seconds walk west, and Park Avenue with all its offices is no more than a minute east. The location is good if you are in New York as a tourist, as all the Midtown shops, Times Square and the park etc. are within walking distance, and several subway stops are around the corner to go up or downtown. The doormen were also always happy to get taxis for us in an instant when it rained, so this would be a great choice as a base for a first trip to the city.All in all, a superb hotel in a superb city and we would definately return if we could get as good a deal again!

Mar 17 2009	Excellent Location Good Hotel	I just returned from a four night stay at the Omni Berkshire with my parents. The location, as many other reviewers have noted, is one of the best. This is my second trip to New York and I highly recommend staying in Midtown if you are traveling for leisure, particularly near 5th Avenue (the Omni's location is right in between 5th and Madison). This hotel is arguably a good value for the location; a four night stay was in between the prices for the Grand Hyatt Central Station and the Waldorf-Astoria on Expedia and I booked via the Omni website!Unfortunately, the devil is in the details at this hotel; some aspects are excellent while others quite poor. The sound insulation in between the rooms is nonexistent. Every night we could hear our neighbors (from different rooms). The first night a couple returned to their room (at 2 a.m.) and kept us awake until 4 a.m. until I shouted at them to be quite. The second and third mornings (at around 6 or 7 a.m.) we could hear children's conversations next door. We could also hear when our neighbors took showers as if they were using the bathroom in our own room.A minor issue that we encountered is the lack of outlets in the room itself (there are two in the bathroom and only one accessible one in the bedroom). Further, although the room had three phones (two in the bedroom and one in the bathroom) only one worked. Positive details include the very comfortable beds, excellent bathroom layout (there's a lot more shelving storage than you expect at first glance), and very kind and helpful staff. This hotel is almost a boutique hotel due its small size. Fireside, the restaurant and lounge, has very good food in the lounge and for room service, but is overpriced relative to comparable options in the neighborhood. Overall, I'm not sure if I would stay at this hotel again only because of the poor sound insulation. However, if I could book at a relatively low price (as compared to nicer options, such as the Waldorf Astoria) I would consider visiting the Omni Berkshire Place again.

Oct 4 2008 	Not the best of the Omnis	Just returned from a 4-night stay. I've been a Select Guest member for 4 years, and have stayed in several Omni hotels throughout the country. This was by far the least attractive and least comfortable. My chief complaint is the misleading room photos on the Omni hotel website for this location, showing Superior rooms that bear absolutely NO resemblance to the room you will get. The Omni website for the Berkshire Hotel described the Superior room (upgrade from the "Deluxe") as a "larger, brighter room facing 52nd Street" and showed photographs of a very attractive, good-sized, richly decorated room with gleaming appointments. Based on this information, I booked a Superior Double Double for two adults and two children via the Omni website. As we were arriving late, I checked in ahead of time via their email early check-in service to guarantee our room. When my family of 4 arrived at 10pm, we were ushered back into a dank, dismal corner of the hotel and opened the door to find we had been given one of their smallest rooms, with a view of a dark and dirty interior alleyway. My heart actually sank - I felt it. What a disappointment! I immediately picked up the phone to ring the front desk, and surprise -- the phone was broken. From the bathroom phone I inquired why we were not given a Superior room, when that was what we had pad for. The front desk's response was that we were indeed in what they classify as a "superior room' (??? How? it was the smallest room in the hotel with an alley view!) but she agreed to move us to another "Superior Room" with more space. We moved to a slightly larger room on the south-facing side of the hotel, so it wasn't so dark, but the decor was absolutely the same as the first -- old, worn, off-kilter, and depressing. Being so tired, we stayed there and tried to make the best of it, but it's no fun feeling like you want to do anything to keep away from returning to your $550 hotel room! On the bright side, the concierges were universally friendly and helpful, as were the housekeeping staff. The doormen, however, would sooner let a lady open the heavy doors by herself on too many occasions.I've noticed the management replies to most reviews here with a boilerplate rubber stamp response. May 17 2008 	Great Value in Manhattan	I have stayed at quite a few hotels in Manhattan, and was pleasantly surprised by the Omni. I have a hard time believing anyone found the staff to be rude. Every single person, from the desk clerk to the concierge to the doormen, was exceptionally nice for a hotel. I don't think my waiter at breakfast spoke much English and he was kind of quiet, but he was not rude or unpleasant, so that was fine with me. I'm not a morning person anyways, and even I was, I don't need someone with their lips on my butt that early in the morning. Or ever, actually. We actually did not need that much space (what, am I going to sit in my hotel room all day like a sloth? I don't think so), but it was nice. My other friend was on 10, and her room was also smaller, but again, same quality, same furniture, same bathroom (right down to the fixtures). Mar 10 2008 	Great Weekend at the Omni	Went for a girls weekend and loved everything about the Omni. The room's (830 and 832) were a decent size for 3 adults per room - large for NYC standards. Mar 9 2008 	good not great	This hotel is nice but not luxury. The room was not very large but the bathroom was nice and a good size. Mar 5 2008	Wonderful Experience	My friend and I stayed with our teenage girls at the Omni for a double Sweet Sixteen weekend celebration in February. There was no coffee maker in the room but there were umbrellas. Of course there is a Starbucks on every corner in NYC and we did get the free coffee each morning from Room Service. Feb 28 2008 	Great location!	My boyfriend and I stayed at the Omni 2/21  2/24 (Thursday  Sunday). I found a great rate of $219/night  probably due to it being off-season. Feb 27 2008 	Brilliant Hotel	We stayed in the Omni for our honeymoon late last year. We had come from Aruba and didnt arrive until after 9pm, wrecked. Feb 16 2008 	Above and Beyond!!	I travel to NYC 4-6 times a year for business and have stayed at more than 25 different hotels here over the last 10 years. Oct 31 2007 	Great time at the Omni	Stayed here 10/26-10/28 room 1710. I really loved this hotel. Great location for everything midtown and close to subway stops. I arrived at 1:00 and was given an early checkin and a free room upgrade. I got a king bed, very comfy. The room was large with a sitting chair, desk and armoire. Came with extra pillows and an umbrella (came in very handy since it rained all weekend). The bathroom was an ok size, and was great for me with just 1 traveler, but would work for 2. Housekeeping was very nice and the room was nicely cleaned each day. There are in room hair dryers, safes, and robes. My hair dryer didn't work. Called housekeeping and it was replaced within 10 minutes. I'm not sure about the reviews stating there was bad noise. My room was right by the elevators and I rarely heard anyone, except for Sunday morning hallway traffic. Ate/drank one night at the Fireside. Nice bar, good food and the bartenders were great. It was a fantastic stay! I would definitely recommend and would stay there again.

Oct 20 2007	Very good stay with one problem	I stayed at the Omni for the first time for four nights in mid-October. Overall the stay was excellent. The hotel is in a prime location, the room was large (by NY standards) and well appointed. Service was very good and always professional. The fitness room was small but the equipment was in good condition.A few tips:i) Sign up for the Select Guest program - it is free and you get free wireless internet (otherwise $9.95/day) and free coffee delivered to your room in the morning.ii) There is construction going on in an adjacent lot. Request a room facing 52nd street and the construction noise won't bother you.iii) I stayed in a superior room - my associate stayed in a deluxe room (deluxe is lowest class, superior is next step up). There is a big difference in room size, location, etc. Pay the extra money and get the superior room.iv) For some reason, catching a cab outside the hotel was nearly impossible. The only time we could get a cab was when someone else was dropping off at the hotel. Don't waste your time waiting out front of the hotel - walk over to Madison and catch a cab there (or walk to Lexington and take the subway!).There was only one legitimate negative about my stay at the Omni - and the reason why I only rated it Above Average and not Excellent. There is a tremendous amount of room noise. I am fully used to and accept street noise as a given in NY and even a little bit of hallway noise with people constantly coming and going. My problem was the extreme amount of noise coming from adjacent rooms. Whether this was because of thin walls, poor insulation, or some other reason I don't know. However, I was able to clearly hear conversations in adjacent rooms and hear the person staying above me walk across his floor (my ceiling). It got so bad one night around 10pm (when I desperately needed to get to sleep) that I had to call security and ask them to go to the room next door and ask those guests to be quiet. Security came proptly, the person was very professional, and the people next door were justifiably dumbfounded that their basically normal conversation was disturbing other guests (I know all of this because I could hear the entire conversation in my room). I found this whole situation to be very bizarre. I've stayed in a lot of hotels in NY and usually they're in old buildings with walls build very thickly or in newer buildings where walls have been well insulated. This is the first time I've experienced something like this. I don't know if this was something specific to my room (722), my floor, or an overall problem in the hotel. I see that management responds to the comments on this site so maybe they can address this?I found this noise problem to be very annoying, but I would give the Omni another try given all of the other positives I listed above.

Sep 9 2007	nice relaxing	The Omni was a great, relaxing hotel. Nice lobby, very helpful front desk staff (Maria is the best), good gym, nice array of toiletries and extra like chocolate on your bed and the ice cooler already filled to the brim :). The rooms and bathrooms were spacious for a NY hotel - I stayed in both a king and 2 doubles, and the room with 2 doubles was slightly bigger. Also, of course the location is great - a few short blocks from St. Pats and Rockefeller Center. The only things I had issues with were the so-called business amenities. Wireless is not free, but you can sign up to their select program, which is free, to get free wireless as a perk. Very complicated! The prices at their business center for printing and faxing were also ridiculous. Other negatives: No continental breakfast, no coffee maker in the room, and no complimentary lounge area with snacks or drinks. Overall, just your typical upscale NYC hotel - nothing special, but you can't go wrong staying here.

Sep 7 2007 	Great Hotel	The Berkshire is well located for seeing the sites of NYC and for shopping. It is located in a side street between the fashionable Madison Avenue and Fifth Avenue. Central Park and St Patrick's cathedral are a short walk away. On arrival we were upgraded to a well equipped 'Executive' room with plenty of space and complimentary morning beverages. However they can't guarantee an extra bed for three people when the hotel is very full so that could be a problem if they are out of rooms with two doubles and only have King rooms left. We we were there during Labour Day weekend and the US open tennis tournament was on so the hotel was fully booked - probably indicates how popular the hotel is. Most of the hotels on Manhattan get fully booked on this Saturday night and prices rise accordingly! We met a retired American multi-millionaire in the bar area who preferred this hotel when visiting New York to other more glitzy and expensive hotels. The must see Museum of Modern Art is close by and if time permits the Metropolitan Museum of Art is also not to be missed. The staff are very professional and the concierge very helpful. We ate in the Fireside restaurant one night which serves good food in a recently refurbished area. If you prefer someting cheaper in the morning then there is a Smilers self service food outlet one block away, and for the evening classy steak houses are nearby. One of the best hotels we have stayed in so no hesitation recommending the Berkshire.

Sep 6 2007	Mixed Reveiw	My girlfriend and I arrived at the Omni on Thursday, August 30 for 5 days and thoroughly excited about being in NY for the first time. When we booked the hotel through Expedia we requested a room with double beds and followed through with a phone call to the Reservation desk at the Omni a week prior to arrival. Unfortunately, neither request was fulfilled and the front desk could do nothing to accommodate us  so we ended up sharing a bed. Upon speaking with the manager, a promise of some sort of amenity was given but the offer was never fulfilled. It was a very frustrating experience and makes one wonder if you book through a travel venue such as Expedia if requests are given second priority? The hotel itself was lovely although we could hear everything in the rooms next to us - including conversations of the occupants.

Aug 25 2007 	5-star stay!	Everything about this stay was above and beyond our expectations. I visit NYC a few times a year and this was my first stay at the Omni, but it will definitely not be my last!!!

Aug 19 2007	Fabulous	For $224 a nigt we had a 5 star experience.I joined their omni club for free and received free internet access and beverages each morning.The room was clean and well appointed. The bathroom was roomy. I checked in online and when I got there, at 11am my room was ready and the paperwork was all done.They let us check out at 2pm.I could go on and on, but suffice to say, even at double the room rate, I would not hesitate to stay here. It was our 4th time. We have never been disappointed.It is between 5th and Madison, which is exactly where you want to be for eating, shopping and the theatre.It was just wonderful!!!!!!!!!!!!

Aug 3 2007	Great location nice hotel	10 of us stayed in 4 rooms July 21-23. That wasn't much of a problem as those rooms had kids that could sleep on the cots but for adults, the cots would be tight. Anyway, the hotel is really clean, great location and staff very helpful. The rooms are small, but bathrooms big. We are all preferred Omni people so we took advantage of the free morning drinks (nonalcoholic of course).Yes, there is construction going on next door, but we were on the 15th floor and that didn't bother us.The hotel provided fresh, free apples while we were there and that was a nice touch.The staff was very helpful in giving directions and making dinner suggestions. We did not eat at the hotel as we wanted to experience NYC.The bedding and towels were wonderful. Hotel soaps and shampoos were some of the best we've had. We would gladly stay there again!

Jul 31 2007 	Excellent Hotel Choice	We stayed at the Omni Berkshire July 27-29. Excellent hotel choice. Very clean and well-maintained. Good service.
